title: How does diffusion happen in a cell? - Quora

response.answer_text: Diffusion is the tendency for atoms to move from an area of high concentration to low concentration. Atoms diffuse because they “like” to be in equilibrium; that is, they are more stable if they are in equal concentrations. In regard to cells, molecules can diffuse by simple diffusion or facilitated diffusion. In simple diffusion, molecules transport across a cells semi-permeable membrane on their own, depending on the concentration of the solute on each side of the cells. That is, if there is more solute in the cell, naturally the molecule will tend to move out of the cell. Molecules that use simple diffusion are generally small and non-polar molecules (CO2, H2, for example).In facilitated diffusion, the difference is that a transport protein helps the molecule diffuse across the membrane. A molecule may need assistance from a transport protein if it is large and polar, for example (can not pass through the membrane on its own). Water (H2O), which is small but polar, must use the protein aquaporin to pass through the cell membrane.When a molecule must move from an area of low concentration to high concentration, it must go through active transport. Active transport also uses a transport protein like facilitated diffusion, but the cell must expend energy (ATP) to transport the molecule. This is not diffusion.
